pli-tv-kd4:0.3: The chapter on the invitation ceremony
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.2: At that time in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country a number of monks who were friends had entered rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:1.1.4: “How can we have a comfortable rains, live in peace and harmony, and get almsfood without trouble?”
pli-tv-kd4:1.2.3: Whoever returns first from alms round in the village should prepare the seats, and set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should wash the bowl for leftovers and put it out, and set out water for drinking and water for washing.
pli-tv-kd4:1.3.1: Whoever returns last from alms round may eat whatever is leftover, or he should discard it where there are no cultivated plants or in water without life.
pli-tv-kd4:1.3.2: He should put away the seats and also the foot stool, the foot scraper, and the water for washing the feet. He should wash the bowl for leftovers and put it away, put away the water for drinking and the water for washing, and sweep the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.1: Whoever sees that the pot for drinking water, the pot for washing water, or the water pot in the restroom is empty should fill it.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.2: If he can’t do it by himself, he should call someone over by hand signal, and they should fill it together.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.3: He should not speak because of that.
pli-tv-kd4:1.4.4: In this way we’ll have a comfortable rains, live in peace and harmony, and get almsfood without trouble.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.1: Now it was the custom for monks who had completed the rainy-season residence to go and see the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.2: And so, when the three months were over and they had completed the rains residence, they put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and set out for Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.3: When they eventually arrived, they went to the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery. There they approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd4:1.8.4: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.2: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re getting by.
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.3: I hope you had a comfortable and harmonious rains, and got almsfood without trouble.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.4: “We’re keeping well, Venerable Sir, we’re getting by.
pli-tv-kd4:1.9.5: We had a comfortable and harmonious rains, and got almsfood without trouble.”
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.1: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.2: They know the right time to ask and when not to ask.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.3: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, otherwise not,
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.4: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.5: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-kd4:1.10.6: So the Buddha said to those monks, “In what way, monks, did you have a harmonious and comfortable rains? And how did you get almsfood without trouble?”
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.1: When they had told him, the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.2: “While being uncomfortable, these foolish men claim they were living in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.3: While living together like animals, they claim they were living in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.4: While living together like sheep, they claim they were living in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.5: While living together like enemies, they claim they were living in comfort.
pli-tv-kd4:1.12.6: How could these foolish men take a vow of silence, like the monastics of other religions?
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.2: After rebuking them and giving a teaching, he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.3: “You should not take a vow of silence, like the monastics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.5: When you have completed the rainy-season residence, you should invite the monks to correct you in regard to three things:
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.6: what has been seen, heard, and suspected.
pli-tv-kd4:1.13.7: This will help you live with one another in the proper way, help you clear yourself of offenses, and help you prioritize the training.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.1: And you should do the invitation ceremony like this.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should do the invitation ceremony.’
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.6: The most senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.7: ‘I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.8: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.9: If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.10: For the second time, I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.11: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.12: If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.13: For the third time, I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.14: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.15: If I see a fault, I will make amends.’
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.16: Each junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.17: ‘I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.18: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.19: If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.20: For the second time I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect. Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion. If I see a fault, I will make amends.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.21: For the third time I invite the Sangha to correct me concerning what you have seen, heard, or suspect.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.22: Please correct me, Venerables, out of compassion.
pli-tv-kd4:1.14.23: If I see a fault, I will make amends.’”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.1: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six remained seated while the senior monks were inviting correction, squatting on their heels.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.2: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.3: “How can the monks from the group of six act like this?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.5: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six were acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.8: “How can those foolish men act like this?”
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.11: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.12: “You should not remain seated while the senior monks are inviting correction, squatting on their heels.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.13: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:2.1.14: Everyone should squat on their heels during the invitation ceremony.”
pli-tv-kd4:2.2.1: On one occasion, while squatting on his heels and waiting for everyone to finish, a senior monk who was weak from old age fainted and fell over.
pli-tv-kd4:2.2.3: “You should squat on your heels until you have invited correction. Once you have invited, you may sit down.”

pli-tv-kd4:3.2.2: “How many kinds of invitation procedure are there?”
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.5: The invitation procedure that is illegitimate and has an incomplete assembly.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.6: The invitation procedure that is illegitimate but has a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.7: The invitation procedure that is legitimate but has an incomplete assembly.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.8: The invitation procedure that is legitimate and has a complete assembly.

pli-tv-kd4:3.2.16: I have allowed such a procedure.
pli-tv-kd4:3.2.17: Therefore, monks, you should train like this: ‘We will do invitation procedures that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.0: 3. The allowance to pass on the invitation
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.3: for the Sangha to do the invitation ceremony.”
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.4: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.5: “There’s a sick monk, Venerable Sir. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.6: “I allow a sick monk to pass on his invitation.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.7: And he should pass it on like this.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.8: The sick monk should approach a monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, and squat on his heels. He should then raise his joined palms and say,
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.9: ‘I pass on my invitation; please convey my invitation; please announce my invitation; please invite correction on my behalf.’ If he makes this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the invitation has been passed on.
pli-tv-kd4:3.3.10: If he doesn’t make this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the invitation hasn’t been passed on.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.1: If he’s able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.2: If not, then the sick monk should be brought into the midst of the Sangha together with his bed or bench. They can then do the invitation ceremony.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.3: But if the one who is nursing him says,
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.4: ‘If we move him, his illness will get worse, or he’ll die,’ then the sick monk shouldn’t be moved.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.5: The Sangha should go to where the sick monk is and do the invitation ceremony there.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.6: You should not do the invitation ceremony with an incomplete Sangha.
pli-tv-kd4:3.4.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd4:4.1.0: 4. Discussion on being seized by relatives, etc.

pli-tv-kd4:4.1.4: other monks should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd4:4.1.5: ‘Please release this monk for a short time so that he can take part in the invitation ceremony.’
pli-tv-kd4:4.2.1: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.

pli-tv-kd4:4.2.3: ‘Please step aside for a moment while this monk passes on his invitation.’
pli-tv-kd4:4.2.4: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.

pli-tv-kd4:5.1.4: that the invitation ceremony should be done with a sangha.
pli-tv-kd4:5.1.6: So how should we do the invitation ceremony?”
pli-tv-kd4:5.1.8: “When there are five of you, you should do the invitation ceremony in the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd4:5.2.1: At one time on the invitation day, there were four monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd4:5.2.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the invitation ceremony should be done in the Sangha when there are five monks.
pli-tv-kd4:5.2.4: But there’s only four of us.
pli-tv-kd4:5.2.5: So how should we do the invitation ceremony?”

pli-tv-kd4:15.1.12: “I allow you to do the invitation ceremony in groups according to year of seniority.”
pli-tv-kd4:15.2.1: On one occasion on the invitation day in a certain monastery, most of the night had been spent with people making offerings.
pli-tv-kd4:15.2.4: and thought, “If the Sangha does the invitation ceremony by means of three statements, we won’t finish before dawn.

pli-tv-kd4:16.1.1: At that time the monks from the group of six invited correction while having uncleared offenses.
pli-tv-kd4:16.1.3: “You should not invite correction if you have uncleared offenses.
pli-tv-kd4:16.1.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd4:16.2.1: Soon afterwards, when asked for permission, the monks from the group of six refused to give it.
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.3: “If anyone doesn’t give their permission, you should cancel their invitation.
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.4: And it should be canceled like this.
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.5: On the invitation day, whether the fourteenth or the fifteenth, in the midst of the Sangha and in the presence of that person, you should announce:
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.6: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.7: Such-and-such a person has uncleared offenses.
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.9: The invitation ceremony should not be done in their presence.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.2.10: Their invitation has then been canceled.”

pli-tv-kd4:16.11.5: ‘I do,’ he should be asked what they are.

pli-tv-kd4:16.12.4: ‘Wrong views and extreme views are failure in view,’ he should be asked,

pli-tv-kd4:16.13.2: ‘I’m canceling it because of what I have seen’, ‘I’m canceling it because of what I have heard’, or ‘I’m canceling it because of what I suspect,’ he should be asked,

pli-tv-kd4:16.22.3: Some monks regard it as an offense of wrong speech, but others as an offense entailing confession. …
pli-tv-kd4:16.22.4: Some monks regard it as an offense of wrong speech, but others as an offense entailing acknowledgment. …
pli-tv-kd4:16.22.5: Some monks regard it as an offense of wrong speech, but others as an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd4:16.22.6: The monks who regard it as an offense of wrong speech should take that monk aside and deal with him according to the rule. They should then approach the Sangha and say:
pli-tv-kd4:16.22.7: ‘This monk has made amends for the offense he’s committed.
pli-tv-kd4:16.22.8: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should do the invitation ceremony.’”
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.1: “It may happen on the invitation day that a monk announces in the midst of the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.3: I know about an offense, but not who the offender is.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should set aside the offense and then do the invitation ceremony.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.6: ‘The Buddha has laid down a rule that the invitation ceremony is for monks who are pure.
pli-tv-kd4:16.23.7: If you know the offense, but not the offender, then say now who it is that you suspect.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.1: It may happen on the invitation day that a monk announces in the midst of the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.3: I know of an offender, but not what the offense is.
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should do the invitation ceremony without the offender.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.6: ‘The Buddha has laid down a rule that the invitation ceremony should be done in a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd4:16.24.7: If you know the offender, but not the offense, then say now what it is that you suspect.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.1: It may happen on the invitation day that a monk announces in the midst of the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.3: I know of an offender and his offense.
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should set aside the offense and then do the invitation ceremony without the offender.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.6: ‘The Buddha has laid down a rule that the invitation ceremony should be done in a complete assembly by monks who are pure.
pli-tv-kd4:16.25.7: If you know an offender and his offense, then say now what they are.’
pli-tv-kd4:16.26.1: If the offense is known about before the invitation ceremony, but the offender only afterwards, the offender should be corrected.
pli-tv-kd4:16.26.2: If the offender is known about before the invitation ceremony, but the offense only afterwards, the offender should be corrected.
pli-tv-kd4:16.26.3: If both the offense and the offender are known about before the invitation ceremony, and someone reopens the case after the invitation ceremony has been done, he commits an offense entailing confession for the reopening.”
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.1: At one time in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.2: Other monks who were quarrelsome, argumentative, and creators of legal issues in the Sangha had entered the rains residence nearby. They said to one another,
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.3: “At the invitation ceremony, when those monks have completed the rains residence, we’ll cancel their invitation.”
pli-tv-kd4:17.1.4: The monks who were friends heard about this
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.4: I allow those monks to do two or three observance-day ceremonies on the fourteenth day,
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.5: with the aim of having their invitation ceremony before the other monks.
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.6: If those quarrelsome and argumentative monks are on their way to the other monastery, the resident monks should gather quickly and do the invitation ceremony. When it has been done, they should say to the other monks,
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.7: ‘Venerables, we have completed the invitation ceremony.
pli-tv-kd4:17.2.8: Please do as you see fit.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.1: If those quarrelsome and argumentative monks arrive without prior notice, the resident monks should prepare seats and set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. They should then go out to meet those monks, receive their bowls and robes, and ask if they want water to drink.
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.2: Then, having distracted them, they should go outside the monastery zone and do the invitation ceremony there. When it has been done, they should say to the other monks,
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.3: ‘Venerables, we have completed the invitation ceremony.
pli-tv-kd4:17.3.4: Please do as you see fit.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.1: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.2: If not, then a resident monk who is competent and capable should inform the resident monks:
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the resident monks to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.4: If it seems appropriate to you, we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code, and we’ll do the invitation ceremony at the next new moon.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.5: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks say,
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.6: ‘It would be good if you did the invitation ceremony with us now,’ they should be told,
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.7: ‘You have no authority over our invitation ceremony.
pli-tv-kd4:17.4.8: We won’t do the procedure for the time being.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.1: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks stay on until the new moon, then a resident monk who is competent and capable should inform the resident monks:
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the resident monks to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.3: If it seems appropriate to you, we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code, and we’ll do the invitation ceremony at the next full moon.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.4: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks say,
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.5: ‘It would be good if you did the invitation ceremony with us now,’ they should be told,
pli-tv-kd4:17.5.6: ‘You have no authority over our invitation ceremony. We won’t do the procedure for the time being.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.6.1: If the quarrelsome and argumentative monks stay on until the next full moon, then all the monks have no choice but to do the invitation ceremony on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.1: “If, while you’re doing the invitation ceremony, a sick monk cancels the invitation of a healthy monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.7.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation ceremony, a healthy monk cancels the invitation of a sick monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.8.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation ceremony, a sick monk cancels the invitation of a sick monk, you should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.3: The Buddha has said that a sick monk can’t endure being questioned.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.4: Please wait until you’re both healthy.
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.5: If you then wish, you may accuse him.’
pli-tv-kd4:17.9.6: If, in spite of this, he still accuses the other, he commits an offense entailing confession for disrespect.
pli-tv-kd4:17.10.1: If, while you’re doing the invitation ceremony, a healthy monk cancels the invitation of a healthy monk, you should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule. The Sangha should then continue the invitation ceremony.”
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence together.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.2: While living together in peace and harmony, they were experiencing deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.5: and thought, “If we do the invitation ceremony now, the monks might set out wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.1.6: We’ll then lose this deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.2.7: I allow those monks to make an agreement about the invitation ceremony.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.1: And it should be made like this.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.2: Everyone should gather in one place.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.3: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.5: While living together in peace and harmony, we’re experiencing deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.6: If we do the invitation ceremony now, the monks might set out wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.7: We’ll then lose this deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.3.8: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should make an agreement about the invitation ceremony: we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code, and we’ll do the invitation ceremony on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.2: While living together in peace and harmony, we have experienced deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.3: If we do the invitation ceremony now, the monks might set out wandering.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.4: We’ll then lose this deep meditation.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.5: The Sangha makes an agreement about the invitation ceremony: we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code, and we’ll do the invitation ceremony on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.6: Any monk who approves of making this agreement about the invitation ceremony—that we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code and that we’ll do the invitation ceremony on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season—should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.7: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.8: The Sangha has made an agreement about the invitation ceremony: we’ll now do the observance-day ceremony and recite the Monastic Code, and we’ll do the invitation ceremony on the day of Komudī, the fourth full moon of the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd4:18.4.9: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.1: If, when those monks have made an agreement about the invitation ceremony, a monk says,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.2: ‘I wish to go wandering in the country;
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.3: I have business there,’ they should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.4: ‘That’s fine, but you have to do the invitation first.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.5: If, while that monk is doing the invitation, he cancels the invitation of another monk, the other monk should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.6: ‘You have no authority over my invitation until I invite.’
pli-tv-kd4:18.5.7: If, while that monk is doing the invitation, another monk cancels his invitation, the monks should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule.
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.1: If that monk finishes his business in the country and returns to that monastery before the full-moon day of Komudī. If, while the monks are doing the invitation ceremony, a monk cancels the invitation of the monk who has returned, the monk who has returned should tell him,
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.2: ‘You have no authority over my invitation;
pli-tv-kd4:18.6.4: If, while the monks are doing the invitation ceremony, the monk who has returned cancels the invitation of another monk, the monks should question and examine both and deal with them according to the rule. The Sangha should then continue the invitation ceremony.”
